Stop notices and emergency safety notices
	Notice to stop activity causing serious harm etc
		If it appears to an enforcement authority that subsections (3) and (4) aresatisfied in relation to a person carrying on an activity in its area, it mayissue a stop notice to that person.
		A stop notice is a notice prohibiting a person from carrying on an activityspecified in the notice.
		This subsection is satisfied if a person is carrying on, or is likely tocarry on, a licensable marine activity (whether or not in accordance with amarine licence).
		This subsection is satisfied if the carrying on of the activity to bespecified in the notice—
			is causing, or is likely to cause, any of the effects in subsection (5), or
			is creating, or is likely to create, an imminent risk of any of thoseeffects.
		The effects are—
			serious harm to the environment;
			serious harm to human health;
			serious interference with legitimate uses of the sea.
		A stop notice (in addition to specifying the activity to which it relates)—
			must state the enforcement authority’s grounds for believing thatsubsections (3) and (4) are satisfied;
			must state the date and time from which the prohibition is to take effect(which may be a time on the date of the notice but must allow a period forcompliance which is reasonable in all the circumstances of the case);
			may require the person to take such steps as the authority considersappropriate to ensure that the cessation of the activity takes place safely.
		Except in a case falling within subsection (9), a stop notice—
			ceases to have effect at the end of the period of 7 days (or such shorterperiod as may be specified in the notice) beginning with the date on which theprohibition takes effect, but
			may be renewed for a period specified in a further notice.
		A stop notice may be renewed more than once under subsection (7)(b), butnot so that it has effect for an aggregate period exceeding 35 days.
		If a stop notice relating to a licensable marine activity is issued to aperson who does not hold a marine licence authorising that activity, the stopnotice may remain in force until such time (if any) as such a licence isgranted to that person.
	Further provision as to stop notices
		Any stop notice issued by an enforcement authority—
			must be served on any person carrying on, or in control of, the activity towhich the notice relates, and
			if a marine licence has been granted in relation to that activity, may alsobe served on the licensee.
		An enforcement authority may by a further notice—
			revoke a stop notice;
			vary a stop notice so as to substitute a later date for the date specifiedin accordance with section 102(6)(b).
		A person who fails to comply with a stop notice commits an offence.
		A person guilty of an offence under subsection (3) is liable—
			on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding £50,000;
			on conviction on indictment, to a fine or to imprisonment for a term notexceeding two years or to both.
	Emergency safety notices
		This section applies if it appears to an enforcement authority that seriousinterference with legitimate uses of the sea is occurring, or is likely tooccur, in its area as a result of—
			any works for the carrying out of which a marine licence is or was needed,or
			any substantial and unforeseen change in the state or position of any suchworks.
		The enforcement authority may issue a notice (an “emergency safety notice”)to any person who is in control of the works to which the notice relates.
		By issuing an emergency safety notice to a person, the enforcementauthority imposes on that person such requirements as are prescribed in thenotice with respect to any of the matters specified in subsection (4).
		Those matters are—
			the provision of lights, signals or other aids to navigation;
			the stationing of guard ships.
		An emergency safety notice (in addition to specifying the requirementswhich it imposes)—
			must state the enforcement authority’s grounds for believing that seriousinterference with legitimate uses of the sea is occurring or is likely tooccur,
			must state the date and time from which the requirements are to take effect(which may be a time on the date of the notice but must allow a period forcompliance which is reasonable in all the circumstances of the case), and
			may require the person to take such steps as the authority considersappropriate to ensure that compliance with the requirements takes placesafely.
	Further provision as to emergency safety notices
		An emergency safety notice issued by an enforcement authority must beserved on each of the following—
			if a marine licence has been granted authorising the carrying out of theworks, the licensee,
			if there is in effect a stop notice which relates to the works, any personon whom the stop notice was served.
		An enforcement authority may by a further notice—
			revoke an emergency safety notice;
			vary an emergency safety notice so as to substitute a later date for thedate specified in accordance with section 104(5)(b).
		A person who fails to comply with an emergency safety notice commits anoffence.
		A person guilty of an offence under subsection (3) is liable—
			on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding £50,000;
			on conviction on indictment, to a fine or to imprisonment for a term notexceeding two years or to both.

Offences: supplementary provision
	General defence of due diligence
		In any proceedings for an offence under this Part, it is a defence for theperson charged (“the defendant”) to prove that the defendant took allreasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commissionof the offence.
		The defence provided by subsection (1) is to be taken to be established ifthe defendant—
			acted under an employer’s instructions,
			did not know and had no reason to suppose that the acts done constituted acontravention of the provision in question, and
			took all such steps as reasonably could be taken to ensure that no offencewould be committed.
		The defence provided by subsection (1) is to be taken to be established ifthe defendant—
			acted in reliance on information supplied by another person,
			did not know and had no reason to suppose that the information was false ormisleading, and
			took all such steps as reasonably could be taken to ensure that no offencewould be committed.
		Subsections (2) and (3) do not affect the generality of subsection (1).
		If in any case the defence provided by subsection (1) involves theallegation that the commission of the offence was due to—
			an act or default of another person (other than the giving of instructionsto the defendant by an employer), or
			reliance on information supplied by another person,
				the defendant is not, without leave of the court, entitled to rely on thatdefence unless the requirement in subsection (6) is satisfied.
		The requirement is that—
			at least seven clear days before the hearing, and
			if the defendant has previously appeared before a court in connection withthe alleged offence, within one month of the first such appearance,
			the defendant has served on the prosecutor a notice giving such informationidentifying or assisting in the identification of that other person as wasthen in the defendant’s possession.
	Offences: jurisdiction
		Proceedings for an offence under this Part may be taken, and the offence mayfor all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in any partof the United Kingdom.

Application to the Crown
	Application to the Crown
		The provisions of this Part bind the Crown.
			This is subject to the following provisions of this section.
		No contravention by the Crown of any provision of this Part is to make theCrown criminally liable; but the High Court or, in Scotland, the Court ofSession may, on the application of the appropriate licensing authority or anyother authority charged with enforcing that provision, declare unlawful anyact or omission of the Crown which constitutes such a contravention.
		Despite subsection (2), the provisions of this Part apply to persons in thepublic service of the Crown as they apply to other persons.
		The Secretary of State may certify that it appears to the Secretary ofState that, as respects—
			any Crown land specified in the certificate, and
			any powers of entry so specified which are exercisable in relation to thatland,
			it is necessary or expedient that, in the interests of national security, thepowers should not be exercisable in relation to the land.
		If the Secretary of State issues a certificate under subsection (4), thepowers specified in the certificate are not exercisable in relation to theland so specified.
		For the purposes of subsection (4) “Crown land” means land held or used byor on behalf of the Crown.
		Nothing in this section is to be taken as in any way affecting Her Majestyin her private capacity or in right of Her Duchy of Lancaster, or the Duke ofCornwall.

Designation of zones
	Marine conservation zones
		The appropriate authority may by order designate any area falling withinsubsection (2) as a marine conservation zone (an “MCZ”).
			Section 117 sets out the grounds on which such an order may be made.
		An area falls within this subsection if—
			it is an area of the sea within the seaward limits of the territorial seaadjacent to the United Kingdom;
			it is an area of the sea within the limits of the exclusive economic zone;
			it is an area of the sea bed or subsoil within the limits of the UK sectorof the continental shelf (so far as not falling within an area mentioned inparagraph (b)).
		But an area does not fall within subsection (2) if it is in—
			the Scottish inshore region, or
			the Northern Ireland inshore region.
		Section 118 makes further provision as to the areas that may be included inan MCZ.
		For the purposes of this Chapter the appropriate authority is—
			in relation to an area in Wales, the Welsh Ministers;
			in relation to an area in the Scottish offshore region, the ScottishMinisters;
			in any other case, the Secretary of State.
		The Scottish Ministers may not designate any area as an MCZ without theagreement of the Secretary of State.
		An MCZ designated by the Scottish Ministers under this section is to beknown as a marine protected area.
		Any reference in this Act to an MCZ is, in relation to an MCZ designated bythe Scottish Ministers, to be read as a reference to a marine protected area.
		Until the coming into force of the first Order in Council made undersection 41 (the exclusive economic zone), the reference in subsection (2)(b)to the exclusive economic zone is to be read as a reference to a renewableenergy zone.
	Grounds for designation of MCZs
		The appropriate authority may make an order under section 116 if it thinksthat it is desirable to do so for the purpose of conserving—
			marine flora or fauna;
			marine habitats or types of marine habitat;
			features of geological or geomorphological interest.
		The order must state—
			the protected feature or features;
			the conservation objectives for the MCZ.
		Any reference in this Chapter to the conservation objectives stated for anMCZ is a reference to the conservation objectives stated for the MCZ undersubsection (2)(b).
		The reference in subsection (1)(a) to conserving marine flora or faunaincludes, in particular, a reference to conserving any species that is rare orthreatened because of—
			the limited number of individuals of that species, or
			the limited number of locations in which that species is present.
		The references in subsection (1)(a) and (b) to conserving marine flora orfauna or habitat include references to conserving the diversity of such flora,fauna or habitat, whether or not any or all of them are rare or threatened.
		Any reference to conserving a thing includes references to—
			assisting in its conservation;
			enabling or facilitating its recovery or increase.
		In considering whether it is desirable to designate an area as an MCZ, theappropriate authority may have regard to any economic or social consequencesof doing so.
		The reference in subsection (7) to any social consequences of designatingan area as an MCZ includes a reference to any consequences of doing so for anysites in that area (including any sites comprising, or comprising the remainsof, any vessel, aircraft or marine installation) which are of historic orarchaeological interest.
	Further provision as to orders designating MCZs
		An order under section 116 must identify the boundaries of the areadesignated.
		The boundary of an MCZ may be determined by, or by reference to, mean highwater spring tide.
		Any reference in subsection (2)(a) or (b) of section 116 to an area of seaincludes a reference to any island in the sea, whether or not any part of itlies above mean high water spring tide.
		If an MCZ includes an area falling within subsection (2)(a) of section 116(“area A”), it may also include an area of the seashore lying above mean highwater spring tide (“area B”) if—
			area B adjoins area A, and
			any of the conditions in subsection (5) is satisfied.
		The conditions are—
			that the protected feature or features leading to the designation of area Ais or are also present in area B;
			that area A is designated for the purpose of conserving marine flora orfauna which are dependent (wholly or in part) on anything which takes placein, or is present in, area B;
			that, without the inclusion of area B, the identification of the boundaryof the MCZ (either in the order designating the area or on the ground for thepurposes of exercising functions in relation to it) would be impossible orimpracticable.
		An order under section 116—
			must designate an area of land (whether or not that land is covered bywater), and
			in the case of an area falling within subsection (2)(a) or (b) of thatsection, may designate some or all of the water covering that land.
	Consultation before designation
		Before making an order under section 116, the appropriate authority mustcomply with subsections (2) to (9) of this section.
			This is subject to subsection (11).
		The appropriate authority must publish notice of its proposal to make theorder.
		The notice under subsection (2) must—
			be published in such manner as the appropriate authority thinks is mostlikely to bring the proposal to the attention of any persons who are likely tobe affected by the making of the order;
			contain a statement of the terms of the proposed order.
		The appropriate authority must consult any persons who the appropriateauthority thinks are likely to be interested in, or affected by, the making ofthe order.
		Where the appropriate authority is not the Secretary of State, theauthority must consult the Secretary of State.
		If the appropriate authority for an area other than Wales considers that—
			the making of the order may affect any activity which is or may be carriedon in the Welsh zone, or
			any activity which is or may be carried on in the Welsh zone may affect anypart of the proposed MCZ,
			the authority must consult the Welsh Ministers.
		If the appropriate authority for an area other than the Scottish offshoreregion considers that—
			the making of the order may affect any activity which is or may be carriedon in the Scottish zone, or
			any activity which is or may be carried on in the Scottish zone may affectany part of the proposed MCZ,
			the authority must consult the Scottish Ministers.
		If the appropriate authority considers that—
			the making of the order may affect any activity which is or may be carriedon in the Northern Ireland zone, or
			any activity which is or may be carried on in the Northern Ireland zone mayaffect any part of the proposed MCZ,
			the authority must consult the Department of the Environment in NorthernIreland.
		The Secretary of State must consult—
			the Welsh Ministers, if any part of the proposed MCZ lies in the Welshoffshore region;
			the Department of the Environment in Northern Ireland, if any part of theproposed MCZ lies in the Northern Ireland zone.
		If the appropriate authority fails to make the order before the end of theperiod of 12 months beginning with the date on which notice was publishedunder subsection (2), then anything done by the appropriate authority for thepurposes of complying with subsections (2) to (9) of this section is, forthose purposes, to be treated as not having been done.
		In a case where the appropriate authority thinks that there is an urgentneed to protect the area proposed to be designated, the authority need notcomply with subsections (2) to (4).
		In such a case, the order designating the area as an MCZ remains in forcefor a period not exceeding two years, unless the appropriate authority makes afurther order before the end of that period confirming the designation.
		Before making such an order, the appropriate authority must comply withsubsections (2) to (9) (and subsection (10) applies accordingly).
	Publication of orders designating MCZs
		This section applies where an order has been made under section 116.
		The appropriate authority must publish notice of the making of the order.
		The notice under subsection (2) must—
			be published in such manner as the appropriate authority thinks is mostlikely to bring the order to the attention of any persons who are likely to beaffected by the making of it;
			give an address at which a copy of the order may be inspected.
		The appropriate authority must—
			make a copy of the order available for inspection at the address specifiedunder subsection (3)(b) at all reasonable hours without payment;
			provide a copy of the order to any person who requests one.
		The appropriate authority may charge a fee, not exceeding its costs, forproviding a copy under subsection (4)(b).
	Hearings by appropriate authority
		This section applies where the appropriate authority has the function ofdeciding whether to make an order under section 116 designating an area as anMCZ.
		The authority may, before making that decision, give to any person theopportunity of—
			appearing before and being heard by a person appointed for that purpose;
			providing written representations to such a person.
		The authority may make regulations providing for the procedure to befollowed (including decisions as to costs) at hearings held under subsection(2).
		A person appointed under subsection (2) must make a report to the authorityof any oral or written representations made under that subsection.
	Amendment, revocation and review of orders designating MCZs
		An order under section 116 may be amended or revoked by a further order.
		The appropriate authority for an area must review any order it has madeunder section 116 if the authority receives representations from—
			the appropriate authority for another area, or
			the Department of the Environment in Northern Ireland,
				that the order should be amended or revoked.

Duties of public authorities
	General duties of public authorities in relation to MCZs
		This section applies to any public authority having any function theexercise of which is capable of affecting (other than insignificantly)—
			the protected features of an MCZ;
			any ecological or geomorphological process on which the conservation of anyprotected feature of an MCZ is (wholly or in part) dependent.
		Every public authority to which this section applies must (so far as isconsistent with their proper exercise)—
			exercise its functions in the manner which the authority considers bestfurthers the conservation objectives stated for the MCZ;
			where it is not possible to exercise its functions in a manner whichfurthers those objectives, exercise them in the manner which the authorityconsiders least hinders the achievement of those objectives.
		If a public authority considers that any of its functions is such that theexercise of the function would or might significantly hinder the achievementof the conservation objectives for an MCZ, it must inform the appropriatestatutory conservation body of that fact.
		Subject to subsection (6), subsection (5) applies in any case where apublic authority intends to do an act which is capable of affecting (otherthan insignificantly)—
			the protected features of an MCZ;
			any ecological or geomorphological process on which the conservation of anyprotected feature of an MCZ is (wholly or in part) dependent.
		If the authority believes that there is or may be a significant risk of theact hindering the achievement of the conservation objectives stated for theMCZ, the authority must notify the appropriate statutory conservation body ofthat fact.
		Subsection (5) does not apply where—
			the appropriate statutory conservation body has given the authority adviceor guidance under section 127 in relation to acts of a particular description,
			the act which the authority intends to do is an act of that description,and
			the advice or guidance has not ceased to apply.
		Where the authority has given notification under subsection (5), it mustwait until the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the date of thenotification before deciding whether to do the act.
		Subsection (7) does not apply where—
			the appropriate statutory conservation body notifies the authority that itneed not wait until the end of the period referred to in that subsection, or
			the authority thinks that there is an urgent need to do the act.
		If a public authority considers that a relevant event has occurred, it mustinform—
			the relevant authority, and
			the appropriate statutory conservation body,
				of that fact.
		A “relevant event” is any act—
			in relation to which the public authority exercises functions,
			which the authority believes to be an offence, and
			which the authority considers will or may significantly hinder theachievement of the conservation objectives for an MCZ.
		For the purposes of subsection (9) “relevant authority” means—
			in relation to an MCZ in Wales, the Welsh Ministers;
			in relation to an MCZ in the Scottish offshore region, the ScottishMinisters;
			in relation to any other MCZ, the MMO.
		In carrying out its duties under this section a public authority must haveregard to any advice or guidance given by the appropriate statutoryconservation body under section 127.
		In this section—
			  * “act” includes omission; 
			  * “public authority” does not include a Northern Ireland Minister or Northern Ireland department. 
	Duties of public authorities in relation to certain decisions
		This section applies where—
			a public authority has the function of determining an application (whenevermade) for authorisation of the doing of an act, and
			the act is capable of affecting (other than insignificantly)—
			the protected features of an MCZ;
			any ecological or geomorphological process on which the conservation ofany protected feature of an MCZ is (wholly or in part) dependent.
		If the authority believes that there is or may be a significant risk of theact hindering the achievement of the conservation objectives stated for theMCZ, the authority must notify the appropriate statutory conservation body ofthat fact.
		Where the authority has given notification under subsection (2), it mustwait until the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the date of thenotification before deciding whether to grant authorisation for the doing ofthe act.
		Subsection (3) does not apply where—
			the appropriate statutory conservation body notifies the authority that itneed not wait until the end of the period referred to in that subsection, or
			the authority thinks that there is an urgent need to grant authorisationfor the doing of the act.
		The authority must not grant authorisation for the doing of the act unlessthe condition in subsection (6) or the condition in subsection (7) is met.
		The condition in this subsection is that the person seeking theauthorisation satisfies the authority that there is no significant risk of theact hindering the achievement of the conservation objectives stated for theMCZ.
		The condition in this subsection is that, although the person seeking theauthorisation is not able to satisfy the authority that there is nosignificant risk of the act hindering the achievement of the conservationobjectives stated for the MCZ, that person satisfies the authority that—
			there is no other means of proceeding with the act which would create asubstantially lower risk of hindering the achievement of those objectives,
			the benefit to the public of proceeding with the act clearly outweighs therisk of damage to the environment that will be created by proceeding with it,and
			the person seeking the authorisation will undertake, or make arrangementsfor the undertaking of, measures of equivalent environmental benefit to thedamage which the act will or is likely to have in or on the MCZ.
		The reference in subsection (7)(a) to other means of proceeding with an actincludes a reference to proceeding with it—
			in another manner, or
			at another location.
		In a case falling within subsection (7), the authority must, if it haspower to grant the authorisation subject to conditions, exercise that power soas to make it a condition of the authorisation that the measures mentioned insubsection (7)(c) are undertaken.
		In carrying out its duties under this section a public authority must haveregard to any advice or guidance given by the appropriate statutoryconservation body under section 127.
		In this section—
			  * “act” includes omission; 
			  * “authorisation” means any approval, confirmation, consent, licence, permission or other authorisation (however described), whether special or general; 
			  * “damage” includes the prevention of an improvement; 
			  * “public authority” does not include a Northern Ireland Minister or Northern Ireland department. 
	Advice and guidance by conservation bodies
		The appropriate statutory conservation body may give advice and guidance asto—
			the matters which are capable of damaging or otherwise affecting anyprotected feature or features;
			the matters which are capable of affecting any ecological orgeomorphological process on which the conservation of any protected feature orfeatures is (wholly or in part) dependent;
			how any conservation objectives stated for an MCZ may be furthered, or howthe achievement of any such objectives may be hindered;
			how the effect of any activity or activities on an MCZ or MCZs may bemitigated;
			which activities are, or are not, of equivalent environmental benefit (forthe purposes of section 126(7)(c)) to any particular damage to the environment(within the meaning of that provision).
		Advice or guidance may be given—
			either in relation to a particular MCZ or MCZs or generally;
			either to a particular public authority or authorities or generally.
		The appropriate statutory conservation body must give advice to a publicauthority if the authority requests it.
		If the appropriate statutory conservation body for an area proposes toexercise its functions under this section in a manner which may affect an MCZor MCZs in an area for which another body is the appropriate statutoryconservation body, it must consult that other body before doing so.
	Failure to comply with duties etc
		This section applies if, in the opinion of the appropriate statutoryconservation body, a public authority has failed—
			to comply with the duty imposed by section 125(2) or the duty imposed bysection 126(5);
			to act in accordance with advice or guidance given by the appropriatestatutory conservation body under section 127.
		Where this section applies—
			the body may request from the authority an explanation for the failure, and
			on such a request, the authority must provide such an explanation inwriting.
		In this section “public authority” does not include a Northern IrelandMinister or Northern Ireland department.

Byelaws for protection of MCZs etc: England
	Byelaws for protection of MCZs in England
		The MMO may make one or more byelaws for the purpose of furthering theconservation objectives stated for an MCZ in England.
		A byelaw under this section may be made so as to apply to any area inEngland.
		The provision that may be made by a byelaw under this section includes, inparticular, provision—
			prohibiting or restricting entry into, or any movement or other activitywithin, the MCZ by persons or animals;
			prohibiting or restricting entry into, or any movement or other activitywithin, the MCZ by vessels or (where appropriate) vehicles;
			restricting the speed at which any vessel may move in the MCZ or in anyspecified area outside the MCZ where that movement might hinder theconservation objectives stated for the MCZ;
			prohibiting or restricting the anchoring of any vessel within the MCZ;
			prohibiting or restricting the killing, taking, destruction, molestation ordisturbance of animals or plants of any description in the MCZ;
			prohibiting or restricting the doing of anything in the MCZ which wouldinterfere with the sea bed or damage or disturb any object in the MCZ.
		The provision that may be made by a byelaw under this section also includesprovision prohibiting or restricting entry into, or any movement or otheractivity on, any part of the seashore that adjoins the MCZ by persons, animalsor vehicles.
		A byelaw under this section may provide for the MMO to issue permitsauthorising anything which would, apart from such a permit, be unlawful underthe byelaw.
		The MMO may attach to a permit under subsection (5) any condition which theMMO thinks appropriate to attach to that permit.
		A byelaw under this section may be made subject to specified exceptions.
		A byelaw under this section may make different provision for differentcases, including (in particular)—
			different parts of the MCZ;
			different times of the year;
			different means or methods of carrying out any activity.
		In this section “specified” means specified in the byelaw.
	Byelaws: procedure
		Before making a byelaw under section 129, the MMO must comply withsubsections (2) to (7) of this section.
			This is subject to subsection (11).
		If the byelaw would or might affect any activity in Wales, the MMO mustsend a copy of a draft of the byelaw to the Welsh Ministers.
		The MMO must place a copy of a draft of the byelaw in such place or placesas the MMO thinks is or are likely to be most convenient for the purpose ofenabling the draft to be inspected by persons likely to be affected by themaking of the byelaw.
		The MMO must provide a copy of a draft of the byelaw to any person whorequests one.
		The MMO may charge a fee, not exceeding its costs, for providing a copyunder subsection (4).
		The MMO must publish notice of its proposal to make the byelaw.
		The notice under subsection (6) must—
			be published in such manner as the MMO thinks is most likely to bring theproposal to the attention of any persons who are likely to be affected by themaking of the byelaw;
			state where the copy or copies of the draft byelaw have been placed by theMMO in accordance with subsection (3);
			state the time within which representations about the byelaw must be madeto the MMO.
		A byelaw made under section 129 does not have effect until it is confirmedby the Secretary of State; and a byelaw which is confirmed comes into force—
			on such date as may be determined by the Secretary of State, or
			if no such date is determined, one month after the date on which it isconfirmed.
		As soon as is reasonably practicable after the confirmation of a byelawmade under section 129, the MMO must publish notice of the making of thebyelaw.
		The notice under subsection (9) must—
			be published in such manner as the MMO thinks is most likely to bring thebyelaw to the attention of any persons who are likely to be affected by themaking of it;
			state that a copy of the byelaw may be inspected at the offices of the MMO.
		Nothing in this section applies where the MMO thinks that there is anurgent need to protect an MCZ.
	Emergency byelaws
		Where the MMO thinks that there is an urgent need to protect an MCZ, abyelaw made by it for that purpose has effect without being confirmed by theSecretary of State.
		A byelaw that has effect by virtue of this section (an “emergency byelaw”)—
			comes into force on a date specified in the byelaw, and
			remains in force (unless revoked) for such period, not exceeding 12 months,as is specified in the byelaw.
		The MMO must publish notice of the making of an emergency byelaw.
		The notice under subsection (3) must—
			be published in such manner as the MMO thinks is most likely to bring thebyelaw to the attention of any persons who are likely to be affected by themaking of it;
			state that a copy of the byelaw may be inspected at the offices of the MMO;
			state that the Secretary of State has power to revoke the byelaw and thatany person affected by the making of the byelaw may make representations tothe Secretary of State.
		The Secretary of State may revoke an emergency byelaw.
		The MMO must keep under review the need for an emergency byelaw to remainin force.
		The MMO may, by further byelaw, provide that an emergency byelaw is toremain in force for such period beyond that specified under subsection (2)(b)as is specified in the further byelaw.
		The MMO may not make a byelaw under subsection (7) unless—
			it intends to make a byelaw under section 129 in respect of the MCZ inaccordance with section 130 (“the permanent byelaw”), and
			it has, in respect of the permanent byelaw, complied with section 130(6).
		A period specified under subsection (7) may not exceed 6 months.
	Interim byelaws
		The MMO may make one or more byelaws for the purpose of protecting anyfeature in an area in England if the MMO thinks—

Offences
	Offence of contravening byelaws or orders
		It is an offence for a person to contravene—
			any byelaw made under section 129 or 132(1);
			any order made under section 134 or 136(1).
		A person who is guilty of an offence under this section is liable onsummary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale.
		In this section “contravene” includes fail to comply.
		Proceedings for an offence under this section may be taken, and the offencemay for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in anypart of England and Wales.
	Offence of damaging etc protected features of MCZs
		A person is guilty of an offence under this section if—
			the person without lawful excuse does a prohibited act,
			at the time of doing that act, the person knows, or ought to have known,that the feature to which the act relates is in, or forms part of, an MCZ, and
			the act has significantly hindered, or may significantly hinder, theachievement of the conservation objectives stated for the MCZ.
		For the purposes of subsection (1), a person does a prohibited act if theperson—
			intentionally or recklessly kills or injures any animal in an MCZ which isa protected feature of that MCZ,
			intentionally picks or collects, or intentionally or recklessly cuts,uproots or destroys, any plant in an MCZ which is a protected feature of thatMCZ,
			intentionally or recklessly takes anything from an MCZ which is, or formspart of, a protected feature of that MCZ, or
			intentionally or recklessly destroys or damages any habitat or featurewhich is a protected feature of an MCZ.
		For the purposes of determining whether anything done by a person inrelation to a protected feature is a prohibited act for the purposes ofsubsection (1), it is immaterial whether the person knew, or ought to haveknown, that the feature was a protected feature.
		A person who is guilty of an offence under this section is liable—
			on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding £50,000;
			on conviction on indictment, to a fine.
		In determining the amount of any fine to be imposed on a person convictedof an offence under this section, the court must in particular have regard toany financial benefit which has accrued or appears likely to accrue to theperson in consequence of the offence.
		Proceedings for an offence under this section may be taken, and the offencemay for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in anypart of the United Kingdom.
	Exceptions to offences under section 139 or 140
		A person is not guilty of an offence under section 139 or 140 if the actwhich is alleged to constitute the offence—
			was done in accordance with section 125(2) by a public authority;
			was expressly authorised by an authorisation granted in accordance withsection 126, or was necessarily incidental to such an act;
			was done in accordance with—
			a permit issued under section 129(5) or 134(4), or
			a permit issued by the appropriate authority;
			was necessary in the interests of national security or the prevention ordetection of crime, or was necessary for securing public health;
			was necessary for the purpose of securing the safety of any vessel,aircraft or marine installation;
			was done for the purpose of saving life.
		Subsection (1)(e) does not apply where the necessity was due to the faultof the person or of some other person acting under the person’s direction orcontrol.
		A person is not guilty of an offence under section 139 by reason of doinganything that is an offence under section 140.
		It is a defence for a person who is charged with an offence under section140 to show that—
			the act which is alleged to constitute the offence was—
			an act done for the purpose of, and in the course of, sea fishing, or
			an act done in connection with such an act,
				and
			the effect of the act on the protected feature in question could notreasonably have been avoided.
		The Secretary of State may by order amend this section so as to remove, orrestrict the application of, the defence provided by subsection (4).
		Until the coming into force of the first Order in Council made undersection 41 (the exclusive economic zone), nothing in section 140 applies toanything done in relation to an MCZ lying beyond the seaward limits of theterritorial sea by a person on a third country vessel.
		In this section—
			  * “act” includes omission; 
			  * “third country vessel” means a vessel which— 
			is flying the flag of, or is registered in, any State or territory (other thanGibraltar) which is not a member State, and
			is not registered in a member State.

Fixed monetary penalties
	Fixed monetary penalties
		The appropriate authority for any area (other than the Scottish offshoreregion) may by order make provision to confer on any enforcement authority forthat area the power by notice to impose a fixed monetary penalty on a personin relation to an offence under section 139.
		Provision under this section may only confer such a power in relation to acase where the enforcement authority is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt thatthe person has committed the offence.
		For the purposes of this Chapter a “fixed monetary penalty” is arequirement to pay to the enforcement authority a penalty of a prescribedamount.
		The amount of the fixed monetary penalty that may be imposed in relation toan offence may not exceed level 1 on the standard scale.
		In this section “prescribed” means prescribed in an order made under thissection.
	Fixed monetary penalties: procedure
		Provision under section 142 must secure the results in subsection (2).
		Those results are that—
			where the enforcement authority proposes to impose a fixed monetary penaltyon a person, the authority must serve on that person a notice of what isproposed (a “notice of intent”) which complies with subsection (3),
			the notice of intent also offers the person the opportunity to dischargethe person’s liability for the fixed monetary penalty by payment of aprescribed sum (which must be less than or equal to the amount of thepenalty),
			if the person does not so discharge liability—
			the person may make written representations and objections to theenforcement authority in relation to the proposed imposition of the fixedmonetary penalty, and
			the enforcement authority must at the end of the period for makingrepresentations and objections decide whether to impose the fixed monetarypenalty,
			where the enforcement authority decides to impose the fixed monetarypenalty, the notice imposing it (“the final notice”) complies with subsection(5), and
			the person on whom a fixed monetary penalty is imposed may appeal againstthe decision to impose it.
		To comply with this subsection the notice of intent must includeinformation as to—
			the grounds for the proposal to impose the fixed monetary penalty,
			the effect of payment of the sum referred to in subsection (2)(b),
			the right to make representations and objections,
			the circumstances in which the enforcement authority may not impose thefixed monetary penalty,
			the period within which liability to the fixed monetary penalty may bedischarged, which must not exceed the period of 28 days beginning with the dayon which the notice of intent is received, and
			the period within which representations and objections may be made, whichmust not exceed the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which thenotice of intent is received.
		Provision pursuant to subsection (2)(c)(ii)—
			must secure that the enforcement authority may not decide to impose a fixedmonetary penalty on a person where the authority is satisfied that the personwould not, by reason of any defence, be liable to be convicted of the offencein relation to which the penalty is proposed to be imposed, and
			may include provision for other circumstances in which the enforcementauthority may not decide to impose a fixed monetary penalty.
		To comply with this subsection the final notice referred to in subsection(2)(d) must include information as to—
			the grounds for imposing the penalty,
			how payment may be made,
			the period within which payment must be made,
			any early payment discounts or late payment penalties,
			rights of appeal, and
			the consequences of non-payment.
		Provision pursuant to subsection (2)(e) must secure that the grounds onwhich a person may appeal against a decision of the enforcement authorityinclude the following—
			that the decision was based on an error of fact;
			that the decision was wrong in law;
			that the decision was unreasonable.
		In this section “prescribed” means prescribed in an order made undersection 142.

Inshore fisheries and conservation districts and authorities
	Establishment of inshore fisheries and conservation districts
		The Secretary of State may by order establish inshore fisheries andconservation districts.
		An inshore fisheries and conservation district (an “IFC district”) is anarea that consists of—
			one or more local authority areas in England that include part of theseashore, and
			such part of the English inshore region lying seawards from that part ofthe seashore as is specified in the order establishing the district.
		Before making an order establishing an IFC district the Secretary of Statemust consult—
			the council for every local authority area that would, if the order weremade, fall within the IFC district established by the order,
			the Environment Agency,
			Natural England,
			the MMO,
			the authority for any existing IFC district that would, if the order weremade, adjoin the IFC district established by the order,
			the Welsh Ministers, in a case where, if the order were made, the IFCdistrict established by the order would adjoin the Welsh inshore region,
				and any other person likely to be affected by the making of the order.
	Inshore fisheries and conservation authorities
		There is to be an inshore fisheries and conservation authority (an “IFCauthority”) for every IFC district established under section 149.
		Any reference in this Chapter to the authority for an IFC district is areference to the IFC authority for that district.
		An authority for an IFC district is—
			a committee of the council for the local authority area falling within thedistrict;
			where there is more than one local authority area falling within thedistrict, a joint committee of the councils for those local authority areas.
	Membership and proceedings of IFC authorities
		An order under section 149 establishing an IFC district must provide forthe IFC authority for the district to consist of—
			persons who are members of a relevant council,
			persons appointed by the MMO, and
			other persons.
		The persons appointed as members of the authority for the district byvirtue of subsection (1)(b) must comprise—
			persons acquainted with the needs and opinions of the fishing community ofthe district, and
			persons with knowledge of, or expertise in, marine environmental matters.
		The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (2) so as to—
			add descriptions of persons who may be appointed by virtue of subsection(1)(b) as members of an IFC authority;
			vary or remove any descriptions added by virtue of paragraph (a).
				An order under this subsection may make such other amendments of this sectionas appear to the Secretary of State to be necessary in consequence of theorder.
		An order under section 149 establishing an IFC district must specify thenumber of members of the authority for the district.
		The order must also specify—
			the number of members falling within paragraph (a), and the number ofmembers falling within paragraph (b), of subsection (1);
			in a case where there is more than one relevant council for the IFCdistrict established by the order, the number of members to be appointed fromeach council (which may, in the case of any particular council, be none);
			the number of members falling within paragraph (c) of subsection (1) andthe person or persons by whom they are to be appointed.
		An order under section 149 establishing an IFC district may also includeprovision about—
			how a member of the authority for the district is to be appointed;
			qualification and disqualification for membership of the authority;
			the conduct of members of the authority;
			the appointment of a member of the authority as the chair of the authority;
			the holding and vacation of office as a member, or as chair, of theauthority (including the circumstances in which a person ceases to hold officeor may be removed or suspended from office);
			re-appointment as a member, or as chair, of the authority;
			the validity of acts and proceedings of a person appointed as a member ofthe authority in the event of disqualification or lack of qualification;
			the validity of proceedings of the authority in the event of a vacancy inmembership or of a defect in the appointment of a member;
			procedure to be followed by the authority;
			the delegation by the authority of any of its functions to a sub-committee,member or employee of the authority;
			the payment by the authority of allowances to a member and thereimbursement by it of a member’s expenses.
		The following provisions (which make provision about proceedings of localauthority committees and joint committees) have effect in relation to theauthority for an IFC district subject to provision made by the orderestablishing the district—
			sections 100A to 100D, 104 and 106 of, and paragraphs 39 to 43 of Schedule12 to, the [Local Government Act 1972 (c. 70)](/id/ukpga/1972/70?view=plain"Go to item of legislation");
			section 13 of the [Local Government and Housing Act 1989 (c.42)](/id/ukpga/1989/42?view=plain "Go to item of legislation");
			Chapter 1 of Part 3 of the [Local Government Act 2000 (c.22)](/id/ukpga/2000/22?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").
		In this section—
			  * “the fishing community” means all persons with any sort of interest in the exploitation of sea fisheries resources or in fisheries for such resources; 
			  * “marine environmental matters” means— 
			the conservation or enhancement of the natural beauty or amenity of marine orcoastal areas (including their geological or physiographical features) or ofany features of archaeological or historic interest in such areas, or
			the conservation of flora or fauna which are dependent on, or associated with,a marine or coastal environment.
		Until the date of the coming into force of section 1, the reference insubsection (1)(b) to the MMO is to be read as a reference to the Secretary ofState.
		Any person appointed by the Secretary of State as a member of an IFC authorityis, on and after that date, to be treated as if appointed by the MMO.
	Amendment or revocation of orders under section 149
		The Secretary of State may amend or revoke an order made under section 149.
		Before amending or revoking an order made under section 149 the Secretaryof State must consult—
			the authority for the IFC district established by the order,
			the council for every local authority area that falls within the IFCdistrict established by the order,
			the Environment Agency,
			Natural England,
			the MMO,
			the authority for any IFC district that adjoins the IFC districtestablished by the order,
			the Welsh Ministers, in a case where the IFC district established by theorder adjoins the Welsh inshore region,
				and any other person likely to be affected by the amendment or revocation ofthe order.

Main duties
	Management of inshore fisheries
		The authority for an IFC district must manage the exploitation of seafisheries resources in that district.
		In performing its duty under subsection (1), the authority for an IFCdistrict must—
			seek to ensure that the exploitation of sea fisheries resources is carriedout in a sustainable way,
			seek to balance the social and economic benefits of exploiting the seafisheries resources of the district with the need to protect the marineenvironment from, or promote its recovery from, the effects of suchexploitation,
			take any other steps which in the authority’s opinion are necessary orexpedient for the purpose of making a contribution to the achievement ofsustainable development, and
			seek to balance the different needs of persons engaged in the exploitationof sea fisheries resources in the district.
		The Secretary of State may give guidance to the authority for an IFCdistrict with respect to the performance of its duty under subsection (1).
		The Secretary of State must give every IFC authority guidance as to how theauthority is to perform its duty under subsection (1) so as to make acontribution to the achievement of sustainable development.
		In performing its duty under subsection (1), the authority for an IFCdistrict must have regard to any guidance given to it by the Secretary ofState.
		Before giving any such guidance the Secretary of State must consult—
			every IFC authority to which the Secretary of State is proposing to giveguidance, and
			such other bodies or persons as the Secretary of State considersappropriate.
		In preparing any such guidance the Secretary of State must take intoconsideration—
			the functions of IFC authorities,
			functions which are exercisable in IFC districts by other bodies andpersons, and
			the resources available, or likely to be available, to each IFC authorityto which the Secretary of State is proposing to give guidance.
		The Secretary of State must publish, in such manner as the Secretary ofState may determine, any guidance given to IFC authorities by virtue ofsubsection (4).
		An IFC authority that has been given any such guidance must provide anyperson on request with a copy of the whole or any part of any such guidance.
		In this Chapter “sea fisheries resources” means any animals or plants,other than fish falling within subsection (11), that habitually live in thesea, including those that are cultivated in the sea.
		The fish referred to in subsection (10) are—
			salmon, trout, eels, lampreys, smelt and shad;
			any other fish of a kind which migrates from fresh to salt water, or fromsalt to fresh water, in order to spawn;
			any freshwater fish.
				In this subsection “eels”, “freshwater fish”, “salmon”, “smelt” and “trout”have the same meanings as in the [Salmon and Freshwater Fisheries Act 1975 (c.51)](/id/ukpga/1975/51?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (see section 41of that Act).
		Any reference in this Chapter to the “exploitation” of sea fisheriesresources is a reference to any activity relating to the exploitation of suchresources, whether carried out for commercial purposes or otherwise,including—
			fishing for, taking, retaining on board, trans-shipping, landing,transporting or storing such resources,
			selling, displaying, exposing or offering for sale or possessing suchresources, and
			introducing such resources to the sea or cultivating such resources.
	Protection of marine conservation zones
		The authority for an IFC district must seek to ensure that the conservationobjectives of any MCZ in the district are furthered.
		Nothing in section 153(2) is to affect the performance of the duty imposedby this section.
		In this section—
			“MCZ” means a marine conservation zone designated by an order under section116;
			the reference to the conservation objectives of an MCZ is a reference tothe conservation objectives stated for the MCZ under section 117(2)(b).

Offences
	Offences 
		A person who contravenes any byelaw made under section 155 is guilty of anoffence under this section.
		Where any vessel is used in contravention of any byelaw made under section155, the master, the owner and the charterer (if any) are each guilty of anoffence under this section.
		A person who is guilty of an offence under this section is liable onsummary conviction to a fine not exceeding £50,000.
		Proceedings for an offence under this section may be taken, and the offencemay for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in anypart of England and Wales.
		In this section “contravention” includes failure to comply; and“contravene” is to be read accordingly.
	Powers of court following conviction
		This section applies where a person is convicted of an offence undersection 163.
		The court by which the person is convicted may order the forfeiture of—
			any fishing gear used in the commission of the offence;
			any sea fisheries resources in respect of which the offence was committed.
		The power conferred by subsection (2) to order the forfeiture of any seafisheries resources includes power to order the forfeiture of any container inwhich the resources are being kept.
		The court may, instead of ordering the forfeiture of any fishing gear orany sea fisheries resources, order the person to pay a sum of moneyrepresenting the value of the fishing gear or resources.
		In a case where the offence involved the breach of a condition of an IFCauthority permit, the court may—
			suspend the permit, or
			disqualify the person from holding or obtaining any IFC authority permitrelating to any activity to which that permit related,
				for such period as the court thinks fit.
		In subsection (5) “IFC authority permit” means a permit granted by an IFCauthority.

		In this Chapter any reference to the IFC district for which an officer hasbeen appointed is a reference to the district of the IFC authority thatappointed the officer.
	Powers of IFC officers
		An IFC officer appointed for an IFC district has the powers referred to insubsection (3) for the purposes of enforcing—
			any byelaws made under section 155 for the district (or having effect as ifso made);
			sections 1 to 3, 5 and 6 of the [Sea Fish (Conservation) Act 1967 (c.84)](/id/ukpga/1967/84?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") and any ordersmade under any of those sections;
			any provision made by or under an order under section 1 of the [SeaFisheries (Shellfish) Act 1967 (c. 83)](/id/ukpga/1967/83?view=plain "Go toitem of legislation") conferring a right of regulating a fishery;
			any provision of, or any rights conferred by, section 7 of that Act;
			any byelaws made under section 129 or 132 of this Act;
			section 140 of this Act.
		The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (1).
		The powers are—

		Before the beginning of each financial year every IFC authority must makeand publish a plan setting out the authority’s main objectives and prioritiesfor the year.

	Power to inspect and seize objects at sea
		For the purposes of carrying out any relevant functions, an enforcementofficer who has the power conferred by this section may inspect any object inthe sea which the officer believes has been or is being used for or inconnection with fishing.

			for the purposes of determining whether a relevant offence has beencommitted, or
			in relation to an object which an enforcement officer reasonably believesto be evidence of the commission of a relevant offence.

		If it is not reasonably practicable to replace the object in accordancewith subsection (4), the officer may seize the object until such time as itmay be collected by its owner.

			anything that is attached to the object;
			anything that is contained within the object.
		Any reference in this section to replacing an object includes, in the caseof fishing gear, a reference to re-setting the gear in the same way in whichit was placed in the sea.

		This section applies where an enforcement officer inspects any object undersection 264.
		The officer must prepare a report in relation to the inspection.

		This section applies to—

Detention of vessels in connection with court proceedings
	Power to detain vessels in connection with court proceedings
		This section applies where—
			an enforcement officer has reasonable grounds for suspecting that arelevant offence has been committed by the master, owner or charterer of avessel, and
			the officer reasonably believes that—
			if proceedings are taken against the person for the offence, there is areal risk that the person will not attend court unless the vessel is detainedunder this section, or
			if the person is convicted of the offence and the court by or before whichthe person is convicted imposes a fine on that person, it is likely that thecourt will order the vessel to be detained.
		Where this section applies, an enforcement officer who has the powerconferred by this section may—
			take, or arrange for another person to take, the vessel and its crew to theport which appears to the officer to be the nearest convenient port, or
			require any person who is for the time being in charge of the vessel totake it and its crew to that port.
		When a vessel has been taken to a port in pursuance of this section, theofficer may—
			detain it there, or
			require the person for the time being in charge of it to do so.
		An enforcement officer who detains any vessel under this section must, ifit is reasonably practicable to do so, serve a notice on—
			the owner of the vessel,
			the charterer (if any) of the vessel, and
			the person who is for the time being in charge of the vessel.
		The notice must state—
			the reasons for detaining the vessel;
			the circumstances in which the vessel may be released.
	Release of vessels detained under section 279
		This section applies where a vessel is being detained under section 279.
		The vessel ceases to be detained under that section if one of the followingthings occurs—
			the notice of detention is withdrawn;
			the court orders the release of the vessel under section 281;
			any proceedings taken against the master, owner or charterer of the vesselhave concluded;
			the court referred to in section 279(1)(b)(ii) exercises any power it hasto order the vessel to be detained.
		A notice of detention may be withdrawn by service of a further noticesigned by an appropriate enforcement officer.
		In subsection (3) the reference to an appropriate enforcement officer is areference to any enforcement officer acting on behalf of the same relevantauthority as the enforcement officer who served the notice of detention, andincludes a reference to that officer.
		If any of the grounds for release mentioned in subsection (6) applies, thenany notice of detention must be withdrawn as soon as possible.
		The grounds for release referred to in subsection (5) are—
			that the relevant authority has decided not to take proceedings against themaster, owner or charterer of the vessel;
			that there are no grounds for believing that any person referred to inparagraph (a) against whom proceedings have been, or may be, taken will failto attend court;
			that there are no grounds for believing that the court referred to insection 279(1)(b)(ii) will order the vessel to be detained.
		In this section “notice of detention” means a notice served under section279(4).
	Power of court to order release of vessels
		This section applies where a vessel is being detained under section 279.
		If, on an application made to a magistrates’ court in England and Wales bythe owner or charterer, or any of the owners or charterers, of the vessel, thecourt is satisfied that—
			the continued detention of the vessel under section 279 is not necessary tosecure that the master, owner or charterer of the vessel will attend court, or
			there are no grounds for believing that the court referred to in section279(1)(b)(ii) will order the vessel to be detained,
				the court may order that the vessel be released.
	Bonds for release of vessels
		Where a vessel is being detained under section 279, the relevant authoritymay enter into an agreement with the owner or charterer, or any of the ownersor charterers, of the vessel for security for the vessel to be given to therelevant authority by way of bond in return for the withdrawal of the noticeof detention.
		Any bond given under this section is to be—
			for such amount as may be agreed, or
			in the event of a failure to agree an amount, for such amount as may bedetermined by the court.
				“The court” means a magistrates’ court in England and Wales.
		A person who gives a bond under this section must comply with suchconditions as to the giving of the bond as the relevant authority maydetermine.
		If any of the grounds for release mentioned in subsection (5) applies, thenany bond given under this section must be returned as soon as possible.
		The grounds for release referred to in subsection (4) are—
			that the relevant authority has decided not to take proceedings against themaster, owner or charterer of the vessel;
			that there are no grounds for believing that any person referred to inparagraph (a) against whom proceedings have been, or may be, taken will failto attend court;
			that there are no grounds for believing that the court referred to insection 279(1)(b)(ii) would, in the absence of the bond, have ordered thevessel to be detained;
			that any proceedings taken against the master, owner or charterer of thevessel have concluded without any fine having been imposed.
		Where a court imposes a fine on the master, owner or charterer of thevessel, the court may order any sum of money given as a bond under thissection to be used towards the payment of the fine.
		If the fine is less than the amount of the bond, any sum not required to beused in payment of the fine must be returned to the person who gave the bondas soon as possible.
		In this section “notice of detention” means a notice served under section279(4).
	Power of court to order repayment of bonds
		This section applies where a notice of detention served under section279(4) in respect of a vessel has been withdrawn in return for a bond given assecurity for the vessel under section 282.
		If, on an application to a magistrates’ court in England and Wales by theperson who gave the bond, the court is satisfied that—
			the continued detention of the bond under section 282 is not necessary tosecure that the master, owner or charterer of the vessel will attend court, or
			there are no grounds for believing that the court referred to in section279(1)(b)(ii) would, in the absence of the bond, have ordered the vessel to bedetained,
				the court may order that the bond be returned to the person who gave it.
